title: 109_s1165
content: The Act may be cited as the "James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge Expansion Act of 2005". The United States Fish and Wildlife Service manages the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to promote the recovery of 4 endangered Hawaiian waterbirds on 240 acres of wetland habitat. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service entered into a contract to purchase land from the estate of James Campbell to protect endangered species habitat and improve Refuge management. Additionally, approximately 800 acres of high-value wildlife habitat adjacent to the Refuge, owned by the estate of James Campbell, have been identified for inclusion in the Refuge. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has identified approximately 800 acres of high-value wildlife habitat owned by the estate of James Campbell for inclusion in the Refuge. The land features coastal dunes, wetlands, and strand that support biological diversity for endangered species such as Hawaiian waterbirds, migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, seabirds, and native plant species. The Refuge will include various species such as endangered Hawaiian waterbirds, migratory shorebirds, waterfowl, seabirds, endangered monk seals, native plant species, and green sea turtles. The habitats within the Refuge are rare due to coastal development. Expanding the Refuge will allow for increased wildlife-dependent public uses like wildlife observation, photography, and environmental education. Expanding the Refuge will provide increased opportunities for wildlife-dependent public uses, including wildlife observation, photography, and environmental education. Acquisition of the land described will create a single, large, ecologically-intact unit with buffer land to reduce impacts on the Refuge and prevent flood damage in the town of Kahuku. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The term "Refuge" refers to the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge established under the Endangered Species Act of 1973. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Expansion of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge to include approximately 1,100 acres of land depicted on a map dated October 20, 2005. The Secretary may make minor boundary modifications to achieve Refuge goals or facilitate property acquisition. Availability of the map is specified. The map depicting the expansion of the James Campbell National Wildlife Refuge is available for inspection at a designated office of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service. The Secretary will also publish a notice in the Federal Register and local publications regarding the availability of the map. SEC. 5. ACQUISITION OF LAND AND WATER. The Secretary may acquire land described in section 4(a) to become part of the Refuge and be administered according to law. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary to carry out this Act are authorized to be appropriated.
